responses.content_en: It is a case of urticaria, a self limiting immunological reaction to drugs, food, bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

This looks like it could be a wart on the scalp. However, without additional history it is impossible to say this is not a skin cancer. You should be seen in person to make sure this is not a skin cancer because it is so large. If it is a wart, you can treat with liquid nitrogen or salicylic acid.
This looks like a pre-cancerous mole. You need to get it removed.

This is a case of superficial telangiectasias, small blood vessels that sit near the skinâ€™s surface and widen and create the spider-like appearance. People often refer to them as "tiny veins" because of their size. They can occur anywhere on the body or face. For most people, telangiectasias neither cause any damage to overall health nor require treatment. However, they can sometimes indicate a more severe medical condition and may warrant closer inspection. There is no cure for telangiectasia, but it is treatable. Laser therapy is minimally invasive and is typically the most straightforward treatment for telangiectasia and broken capillaries. Laser ablation can seal the widened blood vessels. This procedure does not cause much pain, and the recovery time is short. Sclerotherapy is also an effective option where a solution is injected into the veins causing inflammation and hence shrinkage of the veins.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.
This is not a mole. This is sebaceous tissue. You need to get it removed.
You need to get these removed. They're too deep to be simply ignored.

This looks like seborrheic dermatitis. There is some redness around the nose. I have added a steroid cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can take an antihistamine if required. Donâ€™t scratch the area.

This is a fungal infection. You can get a bacterial infection from it. I am adding a capsule to be taken once daily for 2 weeks. Apply topical cream twice daily for 4 weeks. Keep your hands and feet dry.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

This is a case of fungal infection, which is a common cause of itchy feet. Feet have many sweat glands and can retain moisture, creating a favorable environment for fungal growth. Wearing enclosed footwear, such as shoes and socks, and having poor air circulation on your feet can also contribute to fungal growth. To prevent fungal infections, you should:
- Keep your feet as dry as possible
- Wear breathable shoes and socks
- Change your socks regularly
- Avoid sharing towels, clothing, and other personal items
- Wash your feet daily
- Apply topical antifungal cream (terbinafine or clotrimazole) twice daily for two to four weeks
If you have diabetes or other medical conditions that affect your feet, you should have a medical professional evaluate your feet at least once per month.

It is a case of fungal infection. Athlete's foot (tinea pedis) is a fungal skin infection that usually begins between the toes. It commonly occurs in people whose feet have become very sweaty while confined within tight-fitting shoes. The condition is contagious and can be spread via contaminated floors, towels or clothing. You are at higher risk of athlete's foot if you frequently wear enclosed footwear, sweat heavily, share mats, rugs, bed linens, clothes or shoes with someone who has a fungal infection, walk barefoot in public areas where the infection can spread, such as locker rooms, saunas, swimming pools, communal baths and showers. Let your feet air out, wash your feet daily, change your socks regularly, alternate pairs of shoes, and protect your feet in public places. Apply topical antifungal cream (terbinafine or clotrimazole) twice daily for two to four weeks. If resistant to tretmant, consult a dermatologist for prescribing oral antifungal.

Most propably it is a case of post inflammatory pigmentation due to any type of trauma or irritation. Areas of hyperpigmentation might fade on their own without treatment. But to help speed up the process, there are several different types of topical medication that can reduce PIH skin spots like skin lighteners such as hydroquinone and azelaic acid to help reduce melanin production, retinoids and steroids to increase skin cell turnover, and chemical peels like salicylic or glycolic acid to remove skin cells with extra melanin.

It is a case of fungal infection. Athlete's foot (tinea pedis) is a fungal skin infection that usually begins between the toes. It commonly occurs in people whose feet have become very sweaty while confined within tight-fitting shoes. The condition is contagious and can be spread via contaminated floors, towels or clothing. You are at higher risk of athlete's foot if you frequently wear enclosed footwear, sweat heavily, share mats, rugs, bed linens, clothes or shoes with someone who has a fungal infection, walk barefoot in public areas where the infection can spread, such as locker rooms, saunas, swimming pools, communal baths and showers. Let your feet air out, wash your feet daily, change your socks regularly, alternate pairs of shoes, and protect your feet in public places. Apply topical antifungal cream (terbinafine or clotrimazole) twice daily for two to four weeks. If resistant to tretmant, consult a dermatologist for prescribing oral antifungal.

He is right-sided symmetrically affected. It is a case of fungal infection. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply petroleum jelly at regular intervals. Wear socks and shoes.

You have a cyst which has now become inflamed. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily for 10 days and a cream for itching to be applied only at night for 10 days. You can take painkiller on a PRN basis. Keep the area clean. Avoid friction.

This is likely an eczema-type of process and will require avoidance of allergens and irritants. It is okay to treat with topical steroids. However, if it is not getting better or you have other lesions you may consider seeing your doctor for an in-person evaluation.

This is a case of dog bite dermatitis. It usually heals on its own in a few weeks, but you can help speed up the healing process by doing the following:
- Wash the area with mild soap and water
- Apply moisturizer
- Apply sunscreen
- Avoid scratching
- Use topical steroids twice daily for 2-4 weeks
- If it is still red and itchy after that, you should see your doctor to discuss the possibility of getting a biopsy taken to rule out skin cancer.
It does not look like melanoma at all; it looks like the top of the nail. I need to see this again when it is dry.

This looks like a nevus on the nose. Since it is growing and bleeding, it can be a skin cancer; however, it can also be a benign growth of blood vessels. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturizer and use a mild soap.

This looks like it is probably damaged beyond repair. However, if it has been hurting for a while or you have other issues then it could be a sign of a more serious problem and you should see your doctor for additional history.
This is a kind of eczema. I am adding a cream for the same to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturiser. Avoid friction.

It looks like a fungal infection. I am adding systemic and topical antifungals. Take one tab stat and apply the cream twice daily for 3 weeks. Keep it dry. Pigmentation will take a few months to disappear.
It looks like a bruise that doesnâ€™t fade. You can get a cream that can fade it, but you need to get it removed first.

This looks like it could be a folliculitis. I would recommend washing the area with warm water and a gentle cleanser, and then applying a topical antibiotic to help the area heal. You could also consider shaving the area to help prevent recurrence.

It is most a case of contact dermatitis due to contact with an irritant. This can be a detergent, soap, or lotion. Try using hypoallergenic products and limiting the amount of product on the skin at one time. Wash the skin with mild soap and water. Apply topical treatment like topical steroid cream and moisturizer. If available, wear a shirt or jacket to avoid contact with the irritant.
The mole is in the healing phase so avoid trauma to it. You can get it removed if you don't like it.
This is nodular acne. It can be due to cystic acne. You can get it cleared by getting it surgically removed, using topical antibiotics, or using topical retinoids.
This is sebaceous material. You can keep the area clean and apply moisturizer. If it persists then it may require an excision to remove.

This is a case of hormonal acne. Acne is largely a hormonal condition thatâ€™s driven by androgen hormones (testosterone). This typically becomes active during teenage and young adult years. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions, that are applied to the skin. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.
This looks like it could be eczema or contact dermatitis. I would recommend a topical steroid and regular moisturization.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy, or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

You can try painting the nail with a dark color and then sealing it with a clear topcoat. This will mask the yellow of the splitting nail and may make it less noticeable. However, the yellow will still be there. A better option would be to have a portion of the nail removed (usually the lunation finger nail) and have a dermatologist examine it under a microscope. The dermatologist can diagnose any underlying condition and recommend treatment.

A stye is an infection of the hair follicle. Styes are bright red and can be painful. Theyâ€™re caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. You can get a stye if the hair follicle becomes blocked or infected. Some factors that may contribute to a stye include: using a razor blade or other sharp object to remove a splinter in the skin, wearing tight clothing or shoes, or having an infection elsewhere in the body thatâ€™s causing inflammation in the skin. You can treat a stye yourself at home or you can see your doctor for an injection of antibiotic cream to help clear it up. Apply a warm compress several times a day. Wear loose clothing. Avoid rubbing the stye.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appear when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This looks like it is healing from theRingworm infection. The ringworm was probably on your arm or leg. You should keep the area clean and dry. Apply moisturizer. It is normal to have itchy. If it does not heal or if it spreads to other body parts or to other people, you should see your doctor for diagnosis and treatment.

Most probably this is a case of teenage acne. Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles and sebaceous glands become blocked. This can happen when hair is pulled back too quickly, or when you sweat too much. It can also happen when oil production is too high. Acne can be mild or severe. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

This is allergic rhinitis. It gets aggravated during allergy season. So it's important to manage allergy symptoms. Use a mild soap for bathing and a fragrance-free moisturizer. Apply a topical steroid twice daily for 2-4 weeks and take an antihistamine if needed.

This is most likely a case of prominent dark circles under the eye, also known as under eye dark circles. They are caused by increased melanin production in the skin. There are several things that can cause increased melanin production in the skin, including:

Fatigue
Prolonged sun exposure (even with sunscreen applied)
Smoking
Alcohol consumption
Vitamins and mineral deficiencies, such as vitamin B12 and vitamin K
Hormone fluctuations
Medications like painkillers and birth control pills
All of these things can cause fatigue, and it's important to get enough sleep and to manage your time effectively to avoid fatigue. Rest is important for your body to recover, so try to get enough sleep each night. You can also try to minimise your time in the sun, wear sunscreen every day, avoid alcohol and painkillers when you have fatigue, and ensure you have adequate vitamin B12 and vitamin K levels. If you have persistent fatigue or you're worried about an underlying cause, you should speak with your doctor.

This looks like it could be eczema or contact dermatitis. I would recommend using a mild handwash and a topical steroid for a week to see if it goes away. If it does not or if it spreads, you may need a biopsy to identify what it is to have more specific treatment.

Acne is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that is caused by excess sebaceous oil, dead skin cells, and bacteria. Severe acne may require topical steroids and retinoids, as well as oral antibiotics. Acne medications may have side effects, so it is important to use them as directed.

This is a fungal infection called tinea versicolor. It is very common and can be treated with topical antifungal. You can get an infection if the environment is warm, moist, and dark. Avoid these conditions. Keep the area clean and dry. Wear loose cotton clothes. Apply topical antifungal cream (preferably azoles group like miconazole or clotrimazole) twice daily for 2-4 weeks. If resistant to treatment, consult a dermatologist for prescribing oral antifungal.

It is a case of contact eczema due to contact with an irritant. It can be aggravated by sun exposure, so it is important to wear sunscreen. Use mild soap and apply moisturizer. Apply the cream twice daily for 2 weeks.

This looks like a nevus on the foot. If it is not growing, changing, bleeding, or causing any issues then it is most likely okay to leave. However, if it is doing any of those things then consider seeing your doctor for a possible biopsy removal.

It is a case of dermatitis due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

Most probably it is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of rhinitis medicamentosa, a self-limiting allergic reaction to medications used to treat allergic rhinitis, such as antihistamines, decongestants, and corticosteroids. To treat rhinitis medicamentosa, you should stop using the medications that caused it and avoid using any other medications that may trigger a reaction. You can try topical steroids, but it may take several months to resolve. If it is not getting better or if you are taking medications that are not antihistamines (such as decongestants), then you may have a secondary infection and may need a biopsy to identify the cause.
This is eczema. Avoid irritants. Wash with mild soap and moisturize. Apply moisturizer and sunscreen.
This is a fungal infection. I am adding a cream for the same to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturiser and use a mild soap. Avoid deodorant and friction from clothes.

This looks like a skin cancer based on the picture and the fact that you haven't had a new one for 8 weeks. It could be a wart, corn, or skin cancer. I would recommend you see your doctor and have a biopsy to get more information.

This looks like it could be a scar or a post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation. It is probably okay to watch and should fade with time, but if it is growing, changing, or bleeding then you should see your doctor for a possible biopsy.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appear when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This is a case of contact eczema most probably due to contact with an irritant. Itâ€™s a common condition that isnâ€™t contagious. Symptoms of eczema can flare up if you contact an irritant or an allergen. Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day when you have dry skin. Apply moisturizer when your skin is damp after a bath or shower. Apply topical medications to your skin like topical hydrocortisone cream. Take oral medications like anti inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids to reduce itchiness and swelling. Choose skin care moisturizers that are hypoallergenic, fragrance and dye free, gentle or for sensitive skin, contain petroleum jelly or mineral oil, donâ€™t include preservatives or stabilizers, and have lipids and ceramides to improve your skinâ€™s barrier. Avoid irritants and allergens.

This is a case of chalazia, a benign growth of the sweat glands. They can occur anywhere on the body or face. Chalazia are not considered cancerous, but they can be unsightly and may require treatment. The most common type of chalazion is called an emphysema, which forms when the sweat glands become blocked. Other types of chalazia include the following:
Chalazion of the sweat glands: This is the most common type of chalazion and will often require treatment. The treatment of choice is surgical excision, in which a piece of the affected tissue is removed. This will not heal the area and may leave a scar. Other treatments that may be used to help heal the area include laser therapy, electrical heat, and topical steroids.

It is a case of Verruca vulgaris or common warts. These small, noncancerous growths appear when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This could be a number of different things including eczema, contact dermatitis, or urticaria. Since it is present on the arm and there is a history of itching, it is most likely eczema. You should be seen in person for additional history and evaluation before treating. You may require topical steroids, topical anti-inflammatory drugs, or topical antioxidants.

This looks like it could be a wart on the chest. If it is a wart, then it will require removal. You can try rubbing it with salicylic acid soap or lotion, then wearing the area out of home to allow the salicylic acid to work, then repeating the process twice daily for 2 weeks.

This is hyperpigmentation and requires treatment. The treatment for hyperpigmentation involves the use of topical medications and sun protection. The cream you are using at the moment is for post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation only. You can also try topical medications like hydroquinone and azelaic acid to help reduce skin discoloration.
This is fungal infection. I am adding systemic and topical antifungal. Take one tab stat and apply the cream twice daily for 3 weeks. Keep your hands and feet dry.

This looks like it could be a wart or a skin tag. It's probably best to have an in-person evaluation to make sure it's not something more dangerous like a skin cancer. However, if it is a skin tag, it can be simply removed.

This looks like it could be a spider angioma which is a normal growth of the blood vessels of the skin. If you have an individual spot then this is likely normal; however, multiple can be a sign of pregnancy, liver disease, or oral contraceptive use. If you've noticed more of these or have an underlying condition then you should speak with your doctor. The spots are likely to fade if you stop using oral contraceptives or if you have a pregnancy.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

The picture is too zoomed in. In the picture, it looks dermatitic instead. I require a better picture along with history- how it looked previously and what changes have you noticed. Still, if you are too worried we can get hand held microscopic examination done. Meanwhile I have added a cream for dermatitis- to be applied once daily till it heals.

This is lip dryness. Get your hemoglobin and vitamin B12 levels checked. Apply moisturizer. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid lip color, irritants, and tongue licking. Use white colored toothpaste.

This is a eczema or contact dermatitis of the hand. It can be aggravated by allergies, medications, and irritants. Avoid aggravating factors where possible. Use mild handwash and apply petroleum jelly multiple times per day. A topical steroid will help if it is eczema and not a contact dermatitis. If it is contact dermatitis, it can be associated with gloves. So you can try gloves first.

You have patchy hair loss suggestive of alopecia areata. It a type of autoimmune disorder. Eat a healthy diet. Get your FBS and TSH levels checked. Take multivitamins once daily. I am adding a lotion to be applied at night. Injections can be given at interval of 3 weeks. Report if this is progressive or if new patches are appearing because this would indicate a systemic treatment needs to be started.
This is a form of vascular skin condition. It can be treated with either laser therapy or topical cream. I have added a cream to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks. Apply moisturizer.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of fungal infection associated with nail thickening. The treatment for this involves the use of topical antifungal medication on a PRN basis. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Keep your feet dry. Wear socks and shoes.

Most probably it is a case of angiofibroma, benign vascular neoplasm composed of dermal fibrous tissue and blood vessels. Although angiofibromas are benign, they are persistent. Angiofibromas can be removed for cosmetic or pain-related reasons. Options for treatment of angiofibromas include excision,  dermabrasion, using lasers, electrical, and radiofrequency devices, and cryotherapy. Referral to a dermatologist for dermoscopic examination is recommended to exclude basal cell carcinoma.

This is likely a case of chronic eczema of the hands. You may experience itching and discomfort. Avoid irritants, such as detergents, harsh soaps, and vegetable juices. Use mild handwash and apply a good moisturizer multiple times per day. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 3 weeks.
This looks like it could be eczema or urticaria. I would recommend a topical steroid and regular moisturization.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy, or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If persistent, it is recommended to consult your dermatologist. It is also worth mentioning the duration of the lesion may rise Becker's nevus, a non-cancerous large brown birthmark occurring mostly in males, as a possible diagnosis.
